metadata.title: STATIC AND SEISMIC EVALUATION OF AN EXISTING TUNNEL DUE TO A NEW TUNNEL OF DIFFERENT DIAMETERS
metadata.description:
Abstract

The construction of tunnels has gained importance due to their wide variety of uses in the current world of transportation and communication. However, the seismic vulnerability of these underground tunnels is of paramount importance, as they are susceptible to various damages. Hence, in this present article, static and seismic analysis of an existing tunnel is carried out in the absence and presence of a new tunnel of different diameters and placed at different horizontal locations from the existing tunnel.  A 2D plain strain model is created using GTS NX Midas. The soil properties resemble Delhi silt and the earthquake used is the Loma Preita earthquake. Response-spectra compatible earthquake data is generated using SeismoMatch software. The response parameters are generated in the form of tunnel lining forces such as axial force, bending moment, shear force and ground displacement contours. In case of static analysis, it is observed that due to a new tunnel, the lining forces in the existing tunnel increase, whereas a new bigger tunnel creates greater lining forces in the existing tunnel than a new smaller tunnel. In contrast to static analysis, during seismic analysis it is observed that the bending moment and shear force show a reverse pattern. Therefore, it can be understood that the size and spacing of the new tunnel plays a very significant role in the static and seismic stability of the existing tunnel.

Keywords- twin tunnel, alluvial silts, static and seismic analysis.

data.title: STATIC AND SEISMIC EVALUATION OF AN EXISTING TUNNEL DUE TO A NEW TUNNEL OF DIFFERENT DIAMETERS

metadata.title: TwoSampleMR R package
metadata.description:
• TwoSampleMR now requires ieugwasr version 1.1.0 which provides improved error messages.
  • Changed error handling - now if the API gives an error code it is propagated as an error with message in TwoSampleMR.
  • Headers sent to API are updated.

metadata.title: Thesis Artifacts: Design and Implementation of an Automated Testing Platform for Service-Based Software Systems
metadata.description:
Thesis Artifacts: Design and Implementation of an Automated Testing Platform for Service-Based Software Systems

This package contains everything needed to replicate the results of the Master's thesis "Design and Implementation of an Automated Testing Platform for Service-Based Software Systems". For detailed instructions look at the README file within the package. The corresponding thesis can be found here.

Abstract: Design and Implementation of an Automated Testing Platform for Service-Based Software Systems

Modern software systems increasingly rely on distributed, service-based architectures (SBAs) to achieve scalability, modularity, flexibility, and benefit from agile development models. While this can offer significant advantages, it also introduces substantial challenges for testing and validation, as services are often developed and deployed independently and interact dynamically at runtime. Traditional testing approaches fall short in such environments, where only service interfaces may be available and system configurations change frequently.
This thesis addresses these challenges by designing and implementing PIEKER, an automated testing platform tailored to the needs of service-based software systems. The
platform supports integration, end-to-end, and system-level testing by seamlessly injecting lightweight test components into existing SBA deployments. PIEKER provides a concise domain-specific language (DSL) for specifying various tests and enables automated, largely implementation-agnostic test execution and result evaluation. The proof-of-concept implementation for Docker Compose supports functional, load, and fault-injection testing scenarios, and introduces negligible performance overhead in representative use cases. The evaluation on an example system confirms the capabilities, but also identifies areas for future enhancement, including extended protocol support, improved database traffic monitoring, and adaptation to cloud-native environments, like Kubernetes.

data.title: Thesis Artifacts: Design and Implementation of an Automated Testing Platform for Service-Based Software Systems

metadata.title: Ultralytics YOLO
metadata.description:
🌟 Summary

This release streamlines the file download process and updates documentation, making Ultralytics tools lighter and more user-friendly. 🚀

📊 Key Changes

  • Replaced the PyTorch-based file download method with a standard Python approach, removing the dependency on PyTorch.
  • Unified download progress reporting using a single, consistent progress bar.
  • Updated documentation to reflect the latest usage of the Annotator class and added a new GitHub author.
  • Incremented the package version to 8.3.172.

🎯 Purpose & Impact

  • 📦 Reduces unnecessary dependencies, resulting in a lighter and easier-to-maintain codebase.
  • 🛠️ Provides a more reliable and consistent download experience, especially helpful for users without PyTorch installed.
  • 📝 Keeps documentation accurate and up to date, reducing confusion for users.
  • 👥 Recognizes and credits new contributors, supporting community engagement.
  • 🔄 Overall, users and developers benefit from smoother installations and clearer guidance.

What's Changed

  • Fix simple-utilities.md documentation regarding OBB by @mgcrea in https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/pull/21555
  • ultralytics 8.3.172 unify downloads progress TQDM by @glenn-jocher in https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/pull/21563

Full Changelog: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/compare/v8.3.171...v8.3.172
metadata.notes: If you use this software, please cite it using the metadata from this file.

metadata.title: CPAchecker Release 4.1 (unix)
metadata.description:
Changes from CPAchecker 4.0 to CPAchecker 4.1

  • CPAchecker 4.1 is the last release that works on Java 17, future versions of CPAchecker will require Java 21 or newer.
  • Improved float handling.
    The internal handling of floats of the analyzed program was improved in several ways in CPAchecker and is now more precise.
  • Better support for systems other than Linux x86_64.
    Previously CPAchecker could typically not be used for any float-containing program on non-Linux and non-x86_64 platforms due to a missing binary library. Now we eliminated the need for this library and many configurations of CPAchecker now consist of only Java code, which is platform independent. Configurations that rely on external binary libraries (like most SMT solvers) still have limited platform support.
  • LLVM frontend of CPAchecker disabled.
    The LLVM frontend of CPAchecker (used for analyzing programs in LLVM IR or for C programs after compiling with Clang) supported only an old LLVM version and was unmaintained. Now it is disabled completely.
  • The official container image of CPAchecker is now based on Ubuntu 22.04 instead of Ubuntu 20.04 and uses Java 21 instead of Java 17.

metadata.title: Paragnetina lacrimosa Klapalek 1921
metadata.description:
Paragnetina lacrimosa Klapálek, 1921

Paragnetina lacrimosa Klapálek, 1921: 62.

Paragnetina lacrimosa: Wu, 1938: 81, Fig. 75, Fig. 2;

Paragnetina lacrimosa: Claassen, 1940: 130, catalog;

Paragnetina lacrimosa: Illies, 1966: 281, 284, catalog;

Paragnetina lacrimosa: Kimmins, 1970: 344, checklist;

Paragnetina lacrimosa: Sivec et al., 1988: 20, 23, Fig. 8;

Paragnetina lacrimosa: Du, 1999: 307, Fig. 25-6;

Paragnetina lacrimosa: Du et al., 1999: 61, checklist;

Paragnetina lacrimosa: Yang & Li, 2018: 33, catalog.

Examined material. 1 male (USNM), labeled “ Fukien, South China, Cha-go-hui, Kien-yang District, May 10-18, 1933, D. C. Ngu and “ Paragnetina lacrimosa Det. B. Stark 2008 ”.

Distribution. Fujian of China.

Remarks. The holotype is from “Kualun, N.W. Fokien” (Klapálek, 1921), and the present male is from Jianyang District of Nanping City, apparently not the holotype. Sivec et al. (1988) provided excellent illustrations of both genders of the species, but did not mention the collection data of the specimens. The male we examined agrees well with their illustrations, indicating they may refer to the same male. However, we did not find the co-occurred female illustrated by Sivec et al., (1988).

journal.title: A new synonym of Paragnetina flavotincta (McLachlan, 1872) (Plecoptera: Perlidae) with notes on Paragnetina lacrimosa Klapálek, 1921, pp. 137-141 in Zootaxa

metadata.notes: Published as part of Li, Hanyu, Li, Weihai, Kong, Fanbin & Teslenko, Valentina A., 2025, A new synonym of Paragnetina flavotincta (McLachlan, 1872) (Plecoptera: Perlidae) with notes on Paragnetina lacrimosa Klapálek, 1921, pp. 137-141 in Zootaxa 5661 (1) on page 138, DOI: 10.11646/zootaxa.5661.1.9, http://zenodo.org/record/16604524

metadata.title: Paragnetina flavotincta
metadata.description:
Paragnetina flavotincta (McLachlan, 1872)

(Figs. 1−2)

Perla flavotincta McLachlan, 1872: 54, pl. 1, Fig. 9;

Paragnetina ocellata Klapálek, 1921: 61, syn. nov. in Zwick, 1973: 153, Figs. 7‒10;

Paragnetina flavotincta: Zhiltzova, 1967: 852, Figs. 8‒9;

Paragnetina flavotincta: Kimmins, 1970: 342;

Paragnetina flavotincta: Zhiltsova & Teslenko, 1988: 14, Figs.1 −8;

Paragnetina flavotincta: Zhu, Zhang & Wang, 2006: 548, Fig. 2;

Paragnetina flavotincta: Surenkhorloo, 2009: 710;

Paragnetina flavotincta: Judson & Nelson, 2012: 38, Figs. 224−227;

Paragnetina flavotincta: Teslenko, 2024: 109, Figs. 76−82.

Paragnetina neimongolica Yang & Yang, 1996: 115, Fig. 1. syn. nov.

Material examined. Holotype male (CAU): CHINA, Inner Mongolia, Xing’an League, 1983.VII.13, leg. Long Zhang.

Additional materials: 1 female, China, Jilin Province, Antu County, Songjiang River before Baixi hotel, 42.0564° N, 127.5983° E, 9.VII.2015, leg. Zehui Kang; 1 male and 1 female, Russia, Amurskaya Oblast, Amur R. Basin, Kasatkino village, Ganukan River, mouth, 48.95639° N 130.12199° E, 13.08.2003, leg. T. Tiunova.

Distribution. This species is widespread in the Eastern Palearctic. It occurs in China (Inner Mongolia, Jilin Province, Xinjiang), the Korean Peninsula, Mongolia, and in Russia (East Siberia and south of the Far East).

Remarks. Yang & Yang (1996) did not evert the aedeagus of P. neimongolica Yang & Yang, 1996 in the original species description. They merely noted that it is externally similar to P. indentata Wu & Claassen, 1934. Upon examination of the holotype, the dissected penis of P. neimongolica was almost indistinguishable from that of P. flavotincta (Figs. 1, 2). Some minor differences were noted in the shape of the apex in the anterior hemitergal process on tergum 10 (Fig. 1b, Fig. 2c) and the fork of the penial tube lobes of both species (Fig. 1 c-e, Fig. 2 d-e). We considered both species conspecific with P. neimongolica being regarded as a subjective junior synonym of P. flavotincta (McLachlan, 1872) syn. nov.
